captions.text: Second Wind
[Intro Music]

Selaco, rather than being a brand of motor 
oil they only sell at dollar stores, title

successfully mocked, next item on the checklist, 
is a boomer shooter on Steam that was available as

a demo for a while but last week we got a review 
code for what turned out to be a whole, shiny,

sparkling one episode of the finished 
game, now out on early access. Christ,

you&#39;re being prissy about this, Selaco, a 
boomer shooter isn&#39;t like fucking Lexapro,

you don&#39;t need to stagger it out to avoid 
overloading the immune system. Pretty sure

I can cope with the mindblowing creativity of 
clicking the button on cardboard cutout soldier

dudes in a room. While playing as generic female 
soldier protagonist, who looks like Lara Croft

wearing the designated female armour from Gears 
of War that&#39;s like twenty five percent as wide

as the male version and five thousand percent 
more bum-centric. And who seems to be having

real trouble picking an art style. You can see 
her on the Steam page drawn in one art style,

then boot up the game and see her drawn in a 
completely different art style on the title

screen. Then you finish the first level 
to see her drawn in art style number 3 on

the summary screen and get to the end of the 
included episode to enjoy art style number 4.

None of which have much to do with the actual 
in-game art style you can enjoy if you go look in

one of those mirrors late 90s 2.5D shooters like 
so much. This all very strongly signals the fact,

also deducible from the way the Special Thanks 
section in the credits is about twice as long

as the actual Dev team, most of whom are also 
credited with forum handles - that Selaco comes

to us from the amateur Doom modding community. And 
presumably the art style changing is down to them

throwing in whatever key art the nine different 
concept artists provided before one by one they

stopped responding to emails because their mum 
said they had to get a real job. Doom modders are

a weird bunch. They&#39;re people who look at every 
shooter that came out from 1993 onwards and said

&quot;Boy shooters have come a long way, now if only I 
could enjoy the new innovations without having to

play any game other than Doom.&quot; They&#39;ve modded 
Quake into Doom. Half-Life. Blood. They even

modded Doom 2016 into Doom, which is a frankly 
spectacular feat of cranium-bumhole intersection.

And now they&#39;ve made an entire original game 
out of the GZDoom engine, but I don&#39;t want to

sound like I&#39;m ragging on it, like I said in my 
old Doom retro review there&#39;s a directness to

Doom gameplay that a lot of modern shooters have 
lost, even if the sprite-based characters look

like you&#39;re fighting someone&#39;s geometry homework. 
And early access or no, Selaco&#39;s first episode is

long enough to be a game and there&#39;s plenty of 
sausage to get my wet flaps around, so fuck it.

Selaco opens with protagonist lady waking up 
in a hospital room as the hospital is invaded

by hostile soldiers in power armour who bleed 
purple when shot. And that&#39;s all you&#39;re getting

for context. &quot;Gosh I&#39;m looking forward to being 
told the reason behind all this,&quot; you might say,

and you might also say &quot;Gosh I&#39;m looking forward 
to urinating my name onto the ceiling&quot; because

that&#39;s as likely to happen. Yeah, I know it&#39;s 
the first episode so the story&#39;s unfinished,

but even the moment to moment plot updates 
go without explanation or comment. Like,

we get through who knows how many levels and 
without a word an objective pops up saying

&quot;Remember to blow up the cloning facility.&quot; 
And I&#39;m like, &quot;What cloning facility? Why? Is

blowing it up going to stop these purple blood 
soldiers having a beef? Or is this just for us,

and we&#39;re some kind of logical opposite 
of an anti-abortion campaigner?

Honestly, though, I grew to appreciate it as 
a storytelling technique. For despite being

low on direct narrative there is a story, 
the game&#39;s full of text logs from whoever

used to live in the bullet-riddled commercial 
buildings you explore, nattering about how much

they&#39;re looking forward to the baby shower 
and not being murdered by jackbooted thugs.

You discover that the world of Selaco is an 
enclosed compound made to look like a city,

that your character has a secret prepper 
bunker under a bar, and it builds intrigue

without getting in the way of the action. Why 
are we being attacked? Where did everyone go?

Why the secret bunker? Did our character know an 
attack was imminent or do they just listen to too

many podcasts? And as a narrative enjoyer it was 
enough to sustain me through the combat which,

with the best will in the world, has its 
frustrations. Remember how I said Doom&#39;s

simplicity is its strength? You see the monster, 
you shoot the monster, no fancy lighting to make

things ambiguous, no visual effects getting 
in the way, no need to exchange licenses,

bish bash ouch collapse. Selaco thought the best 
way to make the most of that was to pile all the

fucking fancy visual effects back in, in a 
firefight in tight quarters you&#39;ve got maybe

two exchanges of bullets before the whole room&#39;s 
full of more smoke than Joan of Arc&#39;s birth canal.

Playing Selaco feels a lot more like 
playing Half-Life than Phantom Fury did,

and not just because you can hear the enemy 
exchanging grocery lists over the radio or

because it has that same mystifying flashlight 
mechanic where it turns itself off every now

and again for no real reason except to check that 
you&#39;re still awake. The AI is surprisingly smart,

I&#39;d try to lure them back around corners into 
killzones and some of them would figure out how to

exploit the labyrynthine map design to catch me on 
the blindside. Actually they&#39;re frequently smart

enough to be more annoying to fight than fun. If 
you&#39;re close enough to be seen, they&#39;re already

shooting at you. And if you stop for one second 
to look at them you&#39;re already wearing their

bullets as nipple piercings. It might&#39;ve helped 
if there was a little more enemy variety. If you

occasionally went up against something that wasn&#39;t 
a dude in Stormtrooper armor aggressively storming

your position. Like, I dunno, a sleepy dog with 
toxic farts. So it&#39;s definitely a game for those

that appreciate challenge in their shooters, and 
creeping forward looking over their shoulders

every three seconds like a wheelchair-bound 
owl trying to cheat on its maths homework.

So as I say, early access though it is there&#39;s 
enough of Selaco to say it&#39;s a fun enough boomer

shooter and pretty impressive for being made in 
GZDoom. But having said that, it would be pretty

impressive to write out the entire text of the Old 
Testament on the wall of a prison cell in shit,

and I&#39;d still rather you used a pen. Selaco&#39;s 
held back by limitations that we have long had

solutions for. I&#39;m over sprite-based enemies 
in 3D shooters, it now induces less a sense of

nostalgia and more a sense of being surprised 
by an earthquake in a Disney cel animation

storage facility. And then there&#39;s the physics. 
Pressing shift causes the protagonist to dive into

a slightly alarmingly fast sliding tackle like 
she&#39;s just been goosed by a NASA takeoff thruster,

and if you do it in tight quarters it feels like 
the physics engine is having a stroke. I got my

head stuck in low ceilings more than once doing 
that and had to reload before the enemy burst in,

filled my body with small metal objects and 
repurposed me as a disco ball. But yeah, it&#39;s

fine. Now stop being fusspots and put the rest of 
it out. You don&#39;t benefit from cutting yourself

into pieces and staggering out across a wide 
space. You&#39;re not a fucking charcuterie board.
